Description: Two human feet moulded as a single unit: the feet, facing left, are represented from the inner side as was usual in pre-Amarna work. The right foot is advanced. As originally moulded a short length of the foot was included, probably extending to the hem of a dress, which suggests that the feet were intended for a male figure.
Curator's comments: The traditional colour conventions for flesh representations in Egyptian art - red for male flesh and yellow for female - were not observed in glass reliefs probably because of the difficulty the Egyptians experienced in producing these colours until later in the New Kingdom.
Bibliographic references: Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.37, pp.36-37)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1997 13 Oct-1998 5 Jan, India, New Delhi, National Museum, The Enduring Image 1998 9 Feb-3 May, India, Mumbai, Sir Caswasjee Jahangir Hall, The Enduring Image
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
